--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Mark Levison" <mlevison@...> wrote:
> If I'm=
 invited to come and help with a project which is struggling
> with their t=
ests (not having done TDD from the start), I can see using
> the log files =
as a way of helping me better understand what's going
> on. Are there tests=
 without assertions? Are there tests with many
> assertions? etc.

Jester (=
http://jester.sourceforge.net) is pretty useful for getting a
handle on how=
 good a set of unknown tests are and where problems lie.
However, the analy=
sis run taking a long time.   Ivan has written a
simple version that is ver=
y easy to run.  More info here:
http://ivan.truemesh.com/archives/000725.ht=
ml.

There's a similar tool called Jumble that is much faster because it
fi=
ddles with bytecodes instead of rerunning the entire build after
every muta=
tion.  However, that only works for tests that run within a
single JVM and =
I've not got it working with code that does bytecode
fiddling of its own.

=
--Nat
